nodes.text: Klein described the process of projective identification first as an  attack on the mother

nodes.text: The other line of attack  derives from the anal and urethral impulses and implies expelling  dangerous substances (excrements) out of the self and into the mother.

nodes.text: Together with these harmful excrements, expelled in hatred, split-off  parts of the ego are also projected on to the mother or, as I would  rather call it, into the mother. nodes.text: Briefly, projective identification involves a phantasy in which  some aspect of the self, felt as unbearable, is got rid of into some-  one else.

nodes.text: Her ability to see the child as more than simply part  of herself is crucial, not only for her own relationship with the  child, but also for the child’s future relationships with other loved  adults.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The role of fathers and other friends of the mother can be  important in breaking the sway of a relationship based too much  on projective identification.

nodes.text: The Depressive Position

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein identified the depressive position as a constellation of atti-  tudes and phantasies which first appears when the baby is around  three months of age.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In the depressive position the baby (and later the child and adult)  begins to integrate experience rather than to split it

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Awareness of  objects as more whole, with both loved and hated characteristics,  begins. This has considerable consequences. Awareness of the self  as a more whole, loving and hating being can also begin

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Conflicts  between different parts of the self are no longer solved by splitting

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In the paranoid-schizoid position the absence of the good breast/  mother is experienced as the presence of a bad and frightening one  (as darkness is experienced as the presence of something tangible  and frightening, rather than simply the loss of light)

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: An unthinkable thought may be experienced as a  physical pain.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: As the distinction between goodness and badness becomes more  secure, the baby can begin to see both in the same mother/breast  without one destroying the other and the mother/breast with it.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: future. The internal  mother-object is seen as more resilient to attack, as well as both  loved and hated.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In this way the baby gradually achieves a sense  of internal strength;

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: such a good object is ultimately a source of  support throughout life.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: All of this brings with it the awareness of loss, grief, sadness  and mourning

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Guilt, too, makes its appearance in the depressive position, as  the baby realises that the breast/mother it loves is the same as the  one it attacks

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Jealousy arises as the price of awareness that the  loved object can be cared for by someone else

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: but mitigated in  good circumstances by the benefits of being loved by this other  person.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: These elements of the depressive posi-  tion show the link between Oedipal anxieties and an awareness of  reality, both internal and external.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Margot Waddell’s book Inside Lives (1998) gives a good account of  the development of the baby into adulthood and old age,

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: with  many clear examples of the tension between the paranoid-schizoid  and depressive positions.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In the paranoid-schizoid position, anxieties are connected with  survival, with fears of persecution, annihilation and suffocation;  being taken over or swallowed up.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In the depressive position, the  main source of anxiety is for the object

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Real care and concern for  the loved breast in its ‘not me’ aspect, can begin, Klein thought, as  early as three months

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: the baby  also becomes aware of a sense of being too small and incomplete

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: to be able to repair the damage to such an enormous breast/  mother alone.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: It is this concern which motivates the search for a  father: someone who will protect the mother from the baby’s own  attacks.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The alternative is being trapped into a never-ending  dependent relationship with a huge, demanding mother-figure (an  option which some people feel they cannot escape).

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The Oedipal  struggles take place within this context: however much the child  (of either sex) wants to take the place of the father with the mother,  it is desperately important for the child’s capacity to separate that  someone else should have the primary responsibility for her.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Under the pressure of frustrations of various kinds, the attacks  of the paranoid-schizoid position continue throughout life, though  mitigated more and more by a sense of love and reality which can  no longer be totally denied

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: As a result, there is always psychic  work to do, undoing some of the damage of these cuts

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Adults at  times show new awareness of the way they have ill-treated others  such as their parents or a past lover, for example, by mockery or  thoughtless rejection or attacks of some other kind. This recogni-  tion brings both guilt and sense of loss, but also a new chance to  relate differently to people in the future; a better chance of holding  and keeping love relationships. This is part of the maturing  process

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Relationships under paranoid-schizoid conditions may be alter-  nately clinging and rejecting, with caring experienced as invasive  and suffocating

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: True caring and sharing in adult  life depend on the satisfactory negotiation of the pain and anxieties  of the depressive position: tolerance of jealousy and separateness  rather than a furiously destructive reaction to them which attacks  love or the loved person.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In order to be able to care and share,  others have to be seen as human beings with their own character-  istics, rather than simply parts of the self.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: This reinforces the sense of sharing the same world as  other people and can strengthen real caring.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Changes in the relationship to a good object are also sometimes  observed in marriages. An adult functioning under the influence  of paranoid-schizoid anxieties has no idea of a loss of a good wife  or husband, once loved, but is only aware of the presence of a bad,  cruel, attacking one. Therapy sometimes brings awareness of what  has been lost and the possibility of mourning it, enabling a more  loving relationship to emerge.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein saw the conflict between love and hatred as the motive  force for much of what happens in life.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Creative  work of all kinds symbolises an attempt to restore the breast,  attacked and damaged by the baby in infancy.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In the depressive  position these conflicts can be worked on in a way which does  not increase the damage but is creative and loving, allowing the  development of caring relationships with others as well as with  the self.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Objects and Part-objects

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In the paranoid-schizoid position, one-  dimensional, one-characteristic part-objects created in this way are  often used as a ‘solution’ to internal conflict.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The splitting process was  seen by Klein as an attack not only on the person concerned but  also on the perception of reality; as such it is itself a danger to  long-term security.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The story of Cinderella offers a young girl triumph over adult  women; but as a model for a real woman or girl it is lacking

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The bad figures are  multiplied as well as split: the idealised fairy godmother is unreal.  Given the level of destructiveness expressed, it is not surprising  that a small girl should prefer not to own it, but to see herself  instead as the Cinderella victim

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Reality would require a small girl to reinstate her envied mother  and suffer the fact that her parents have their own lives and a sex-  ual relationship and that she must wait for adulthood herself: the  gain would be that she no longer had to sit in the cinders or to  deny herself a real mother

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: She would also have to see the injustice  of her view of her mother as an envious, wicked step-mother, and  her own culpability when it came to envious and jealous attacks

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Regaining awareness of her own envy and jealousy would bring at  the same time both guilt and loss (of idealisation of herself and her  ‘dead’ mother) and an increase in her sense of her own strength  and her closeness to her real mother.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The creation of part-objects in this way is an illustration of  Klein’s belief that idealisation is a defence against persecutory  phantasies rather than reality.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: under the influence of the depressive position the infant becomes  much more aware of whole objects, in which characteristics felt to  be good and loved coexist with characteristics felt to be bad, hated  and feared

nodes.text: Internal and External Objects

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein distinguished between the external mother and phantasies of  the mother both inside and outside the self.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Part of the process of

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: development (and of therapy) involves the building up of a  resilient internal mother-figure, a ‘good object’, which can survive  attack, be the object of love and care, and provide a sense of being  loved and cared for.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: This good internal mother-figure is built up not  only out of real experiences of being loved (not just by the mother  but by other people too), but also out of the child’s experience of  loving

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: When children call their teacher ‘mum’ or their mother ‘Miss’  they are demonstrating how the internal good mother phantasy is  used to relate to and understand other women as well as the  mother.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Children do sometimes split parents and  step-parents into good and bad but this is itself a result of bad  relations carrying over.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: During the process of loss, phantasies of the goodness of  the object may be under attack.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The child who says ‘she wasn’t  worth having anyway’ or ‘I’m better than she is’ in response to  losing his mother’s attention to a new brother, for example, has  not only lost his external mother but has also denigrated his phan-  tasy internal mother

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: It is only when the pain of grief can be withstood that the child  or adult can say ‘She was good and I’ve lost her.’

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Children need  adults who care for them if they are to maintain a belief that ‘inside  me I can feel she still loves me’.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Without this their belief in the exis-  tence of a loving self and in their own ability to love without  destroying is under threat.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Development of Sexuality

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein agreed with Freud that the original relationship with the  mother was the basis for later sexual and marital relationships.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: differed from  Freud (and some present-day analysts) in her belief that the baby,  child and adult at depth seek someone who is different from them-  selves and has something more to offer, not just a repeat of an  earlier relationship with themselves.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: saw feeding experiences as the basis for genital sexual feel-  ings as well as believing that there was an innate awareness of the  sexual act and its meaning.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Where feeding phantasies have been  predominantly good, the phantasies governing sexual relationships  will be predominantly good.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Sex will be understood as a mutual  gratification, a good relationship in which each partner feeds and  is fed by the other emotionally as well as in the giving and taking  of genital pleasure.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: ‘Something good’ can be felt to come out of the  relationship: whether it is babies or some other kind of creativity  in which both partners are enriched

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: this  gives deep and resonant meaning to sexual activities of all kinds.  In phantasy, the attachment of sexual organs to the people they  belong to will be firm and valued.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Phantasies used to understand genital sex also include bad ones.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: People may be rejected and only their sexual organs  desired.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Instead of love, loving and creativity, sexuality may be  understood to produce destructiveness, damage and a diminish-  ing of both partners

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Masturbatory pleasure can be used to deny the need for a relation-  ship with another real person: a relationship which may not have  been available or which may have been rejected.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Underneath this  idealisation of the baby’s own ability to satisfy itself are hidden  very disturbing phantasies of attacks on the object which does not  provide the gratification desired

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein found that masturbation in childhood could involve very  sadistic and cruel fantasies directed at parents felt as neglectful:  some of the guilt children normally feel towards masturbation may  be attached to such fantasies

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: She also described instances of children  involved in sexual relations with brothers and sisters, and traced  some of the very distressing phantasies and the unconscious guilt  the children felt in connection with this.

nodes.text: Fathers

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein’s view of fathers was not quite the same as Freud’s.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Her  emphasis on the role of the mother has led to her being accused  of ignoring the father, while Freud has been accused of playing  down the role of the mother.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: She saw the father both as an object of the baby’s and  child’s love in his own right, and as someone who forces the baby  to learn about three-way relationships, playing a vital part in  enabling the baby to grow up and separate from the mother, with  a mind and body of his or her own.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Although the father’s relationship with  the mother makes the baby jealous and rivalrous, he is also felt to  provide important boundaries, preventing mother and baby  getting too entangled with each other

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: His different way of caring  for the baby is also important.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Depending on circumstances  he can take on and represent in phantasy not only the baby’s

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: aggressiveness and power, perhaps, but also more caring and  creative aspects

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Freud thought that a girl wanted her father primarily to give her  a penis for herself, in order that she could be a man

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Elizabeth  Spillius (1988) says that many of Freud’s patients were young  women with what we now call conversion symptoms: present-day  understanding is that such women very often idealise and desire a  penis for themselves and are denigrating towards their mothers  and towards men as love objects.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Freud’s theory would apply to  these women.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: (Conversion symptoms are symptoms created by  the conversion of emotional feelings into physical ones: a stomach  ache instead of an anxiety-provoking thought, for example, or a  paralysis of the hand instead of an acknowledgement of anxieties  connected with writing cheques.)

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Spillius, Elizabeth Bott (ed.) (1988) Melanie Klein Today, 2 vols. Vol. I: Mainly Theory.  Vol. II: Mainly Practice, London: Routledge and the Institute of Psychoanalysis.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein, however, had a much wider view.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: She felt that in good circumstances loving phantasies,  derived from the relationship with the breast as an object of desire  and affection, were the foundation for loving phantasies of the  father as well as of the mother

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: ways. Love for the  breast and love experienced from the breast ‘spills over’ into love  for the whole world and all in it

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: These people are seen as allies in the  task of restoring her and repairing the damage done to her in  phantasy.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: A father by his behaviour may, for example, reassure the child  that firmness, authority and love can mutually coexist.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Equally he  may convince the child that authority means cruelty and love  means rejection and victimisation.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In the absence of a father, children  will create a phantasy idealised one. Their anger towards this  abandoning father may make the negative phantasies very fright-  ening

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Equally, people who are constantly trying not to be like  an actual parent may appear false and superficial because they  cannot behave spontaneously for fear of betraying themselves

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Fathers, in Klein’s view, are more important to children than  people often recognise. Absent fathers continue to play an enor-  mous part in children’s fantasy worlds, both conscious and uncon-  scious.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The role of the father is also important in current Kleinian thinking  about the containing function

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The Oedipal triangle, in which  mother and baby are connected and supported by a third party  who is attached to both, has importance not only in practical terms  but also symbolically.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In order to allow the mother to think, the  baby has to tolerate her having space in her own mind which is not  invaded by the baby

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: existence. The father can help  the baby in many ways to allow the mother to have space in her  own mind for her own thoughts, sometimes shared with him.

nodes.text: Babies

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Freud thought that, at depth, girls wanted babies as a substitute for  the penis they did not have: in other words, primarily as part of  their relationship with themselves and their own bodies.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein  thought that girls under normal conditions wanted babies for  much more complex reasons

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: She thought that if they did want  them as substitutes for a penis of their own then this was patho-  logical and would not be the basis for a good relationship with the  baby.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Some women, under the influence of more paranoid-schizoid  anxieties, do, as Freud thought, want a baby to decorate themselves,

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein saw this as a cover-up for

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: phantasies of being empty and having nothing insid

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In happier circumstances the baby will at times represent some  part of the mother without being completely identified with it.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: All  mothers probably see themselves in their babies at times: at other  times they may see the baby as standing for their own loved and lov-  ing internal mother.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: They may also see the baby at times as standing  for a persecuting and demanding internal mother-figure: bigger than  the mother herself and sucking her dry

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Mothering can be exhaust-  ing, and such phantasies both express and contribute to the exhaus-  tion.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Anxiety

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In Freud’s earlier writings he describes anxiety as deriving from  inhibited sexuality. Frustrated sexual feelings, he thought, were  converted into feelings of anxiety.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Later, in ‘Inhibitions, Symptoms  and Anxiety’ (1926) he changed this view and linked anxiety to a  fear of the loss of the object:

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: originally the mother who protects the  baby from the danger of ‘being hopelessly exposed to an unplea-  surable tension due to instinctual need’

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Later this transforms into  fear of loss of the penis which he describes as an organ which  would allow the child to ‘be once more united to his mother – i.e.  to a substitute for her – in the act of copulation’ (Freud, 1975,  vol. 20: 139).

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Still later this is modified into a fear of the super-ego,  and later still, into ‘a fear of death (or fear for life) which is a fear  of the super-ego projected on to the powers of destiny’.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein’s views about anxiety, like Freud’s, evolved.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: in her paper ‘The Early Development of  Conscience in the Child’ (Klein, 1975, vol. I), she describes perse-  cutory anxiety as arising from the child’s fear of its own aggressive  impulses

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: ‘persecutory’ anxiety, in which the fear is of being  attacked and destroyed oneself;

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Persecutory anxiety she saw as part of the paranoid-schizoid posi-  tion. Too frightening to handle by talking or thinking, it is often  dealt with by projective identification

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: In ‘A Contribution to the Psychogenesis of Manic-  Depressive States’ (1935, ibid.) she goes on to describe two kinds of  anxiety;

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: ‘depressive’ anxiety, in which  the fear is of losing or damaging someone who is loved.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Depressive anxiety has a different quality to it

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: involves recognition of the goodness of the lost loved

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: anxiety can be held  within the self and is a stimulus to attempt to make things better:

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Through symbolic reparation  anxiety of a bearable kind becomes a stimulus to creative work.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Anxiety plays an important role in Kleinian theory and prac-  tice.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: It is by seeking the source of a present anxiety and modify-  ing it that an analyst brings relief to a patient

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Mechanisms such as  splitting, disintegration and denial take place under the pressure  of persecutory anxieties;

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: integration  and acceptance of reality may be ways of dealing with depres-  sive anxieties

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Klein saw this  as strengthening the ego through reducing the need of the patient  to split off aspects of the self and attribute these to others, includ-  ing the super-ego (the conscience or critical internal parents).

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: development depends on  tolerating and working through anxiety

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Where anxiety is simply  expelled, it is not available to create the necessary conditions for  change within the psyche

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: What matters is the way anxiety is han-  dled, which depends in turn both on the quality of the anxiety  involved, and the capacity to bear it.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: The presence or absence of a  loved, thinking person at certain times in life can have a powerful  effect on the capacity to manage anxiety in a life-enhancing way.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: understood that the processes of splitting the object into  bad and good, ideal and terrifyingly persecuting, itself became a  threat after a time

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: when people go to war. A  view of other people as real human beings who hurt and suffer is  split off from a view which sees them as the enemy, deserving only  to die.

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: splitting a mother into a fairy godmother and a  wicked step-mother is a distortion of reality

ref.doc: melanie klein (key figures in counselling and psychotherapy series)

nodes.text: Splitting is an action  undertaken in phantasy which can be used to separate things  which belong together
